title: A Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Relapse Prevention Study of Pimavanserin for the Treatment of Hallucinations and Delusions Associated With Dementia-related Psychosis
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of pimavanserin compared to placebo in preventing relapse of psychotic symptoms in subjects with dementia-related psychosis who responded to 12 weeks of open label pimavanserin treatment.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: During the screening period, subjects were assessed for study eligibility and prohibited medications were discontinued when medically appropriate. Subjects and partner/caregivers also received a standardized psychosocial therapy training.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: The study was performed in subjects with all-cause dementia according to NIA-AA guidelines, including dementia associated with Parkinson's disease, dementia with Lewy Bodies, possible or probable Alzheimer's disease, frontotemporal degeneration spectrum disorder, and/or vascular dementia, and were to have had at least a 2-month history of psychotic symptoms.

groups.title: Pimavanserin Open-Label Period
groups.description: Pimavanserin 34 mg once daily, with the possibility to adjust to pimavanserin 20 mg once daily between Weeks 1 and 4 based on tolerability. After Week 4, the dose of study drug remained fixed at either 34 or 20 mg once daily.

groups.title: Pimavanserin Double-Blind Period
groups.description: Pimavanserin 34 mg once daily or pimavanserin 20 mg once daily (the dose at which patients completed the Open-Label Period) for 26 weeks or until relapse

groups.title: Placebo Double-Blind Period
groups.description: Placebo once daily for 26 weeks or until relapse

dropWithdraws.type: Lack of Response in OL period

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: Patients who entered the respective study period and received at least one dose of study medication

groups.title: Pimavanserin Open-Label Period
groups.description: Pimavanserin 34 mg once daily, with the possibility to adjust to pimavanserin 20 mg once daily between Weeks 1 and 4 based on tolerability. After Week 4, the dose of study drug remained fixed at either 34 or 20 mg once daily.

measures.title: Race (NIH/OMB)
measures.populationDescription: For 8 patients, Information on race was not available.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms-Hallucinations+Delusions (SAPS-H+D) total score
measures.description: The Scale for the Assessment of Positive Symptoms-Hallucinations and Delusions (SAPS-H+D) is a 20-item scale; the total score is the sum of the 20 item scores (range 0-100); higher scores denote more severe symptoms.

measures.title: Clinical Global Impression-Severity (CGI-S)
measures.description: The Clinical Global Impression-Severity (CGI-S) is a clinician-rated, 7-point scale to rate the severity of the patient's hallucinations and delusions at the time of assessment. Scores range from 1 to 7, with a higher score marking a more severe state.

outcomeMeasures.title: Time From Randomization to Relapse in the Double-blind (DB) Period
outcomeMeasures.description:
The time from randomization to relapse in the DB period was compared between treatment groups using a Cox regression model. The treatment effect was measured by the hazard ratio (HR).

Relapse was defined as (1) ≥30% increase in SAPS-H+D total score from DB baseline (BL) and CGI-I score ≥6 relative to DB BL, (2) treatment with antipsychotic for dementia-related delusions/hallucinations, (3) treatment/study discontinuation due to lack of efficacy, and/or (4) hospitalization for worsening dementia-related psychosis.

SAPS-H+D is a 20-item scale; the total score is the sum of the 20 item scores (range 0-100); higher scores denote more severe symptoms. CGI-I is a clinician-rated 7-point scale to rate improvement in hallucinations/delusions relative to BL (range 1-7); higher scores denote less improvement or worsening.

A pre-specified IA was conducted after accrual of 40 adjudicated relapse events. The prespecified stopping criterion was met; the study was stopped for efficacy.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients randomized on or before the database cutoff date for the IA (i.e., when 40 adjudicated relapse events had accrued).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: From randomization in the DB period through 26 weeks

groups.title: Pimavanserin Double-Blind Period
groups.description: Pimavanserin 34 mg once daily or pimavanserin 20 mg once daily (the dose at which patients completed the Open-Label Period) for 26 weeks or until relapse

groups.title: Placebo Double-Blind Period
groups.description: Placebo once daily for 26 weeks or until relapse

measurements.comment: The median time to relapse could not be estimated as the Kaplan-Meier probability estimate of relapse over the 26-week DB period did not exceed 50%.
The median time to relapse could not be estimated as the Kaplan-Meier probability estimate of relapse over the 26-week DB period did not exceed 50%.

analyses.pValueComment: 1-sided p-value reported. The protocol-defined O'Brien Flemming stopping boundary for the planned IA was a 1-sided p-value equal to 0.0033
analyses.estimateComment: Model included covariates for Treatment group, dementia subtype, and region, and robust sandwich-type variance estimator.

outcomeMeasures.title: Time From Randomization to Discontinuation From the DB Period for Any Reason
outcomeMeasures.description: The endpoint of time from randomization to discontinuation from the DB period for any reason (other than termination of the study by the sponsor) was compared between treatment groups using a Cox regression model. The treatment effect was measured by the HR.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All patients randomized on or before the database cutoff date for the IA (i.e., when 40 adjudicated relapse events had accrued).
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: From randomization in the DB period through 26 weeks

groups.description: Placebo once daily for 26 weeks or until relapse

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse Events (AEs) were to be documented through 30 days after the last dose in the study.

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certainAgreement.otherDetails: Investigator may publish the study results, relative to their own patients, only after review, comment and approval by the sponsor. No publication of confidential information shall be made without the sponsor's prior written consent. At least 60 days prior to submitting a manuscript or prior to any public presentation, a copy of the manuscript or presentation will be provided to the Sponsor for review and comment. The sponsor has 60 days to review and comment.

pointOfContact.title: Sr. Dir. Medical Information and Medical Communications

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests pimavanserin to prevent relapse of hallucinations and delusions (psychotic symptoms) in dementia-related psychosis, i.e., it targets neuropsychiatric symptoms rather than Alzheimer’s pathology or cognition. Pimavanserin is a 5‑HT2A receptor inverse agonist (an antipsychotic), not a biologic targeting amyloid or tau. citeturn0search6turn0search2.

Act: Key extracted details — drug: pimavanserin (marketed as Nuplazid); intervention: continue pimavanserin versus placebo after a 12‑week open‑label response period; primary outcome: time to relapse of psychosis (relapse‑prevention design). These trial design and result descriptions match the HARMONY dementia‑related psychosis study. citeturn0search2turn0search4turn0search1.

Reflect: Classification check — by the provided category definitions, pimavanserin is not a disease‑targeted biologic (it is not a monoclonal antibody or vaccine) and, although a small molecule, it does not target Alzheimer’s pathology (amyloid/tau) so it does not meet the “disease‑targeted small molecule” category. Its mechanism and the trial goal (preventing psychosis relapse) clearly place it in the neuropsychiatric symptom improvement category. No ambiguity remains from the description. citeturn0search6turn0search2.

Web search results (sources used): 1) FDA summary and safety information for Nuplazid (pimavanserin) — approval context and safety warnings. citeturn0search0. 2) HARMONY trial publications/abstracts describing the open‑label 12‑week pimavanserin run‑in and randomized relapse‑prevention phase (trial population, endpoints, and results). citeturn0search2turn0search4turn0search1. 3) Pharmacology references describing pimavanserin as a 5‑HT2A inverse agonist with antipsychotic effects and low dopamine receptor activity. citeturn0search6.
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests pimavanserin (Nuplazid), a small‑molecule inverse agonist/antagonist at the serotonin 5‑HT2A receptor to prevent relapse of hallucinations and delusions (neuropsychiatric symptoms). This is a drug acting on a neurotransmitter receptor, not on Alzheimer’s pathology (amyloid/tau) or disease‑modifying pathways. citeturn1search2turn1search3

Act: Extracted details and assignment — drug: pimavanserin (Nuplazid); mechanism: selective 5‑HT2A inverse agonist/antagonist; indication in the trial: relapse‑prevention of dementia‑related psychosis (HARMONY design: 12‑week open‑label stabilization then randomized continuation vs placebo). Based on that mechanism and intent, assign D) Neurotransmitter Receptors. citeturn1search1turn2search0turn2search3

Reflect: Confirming the fit — CADRO category D covers interventions that modulate neurotransmitter receptors (e.g., serotonergic, dopaminergic agents). Pimavanserin’s selective serotonergic (5‑HT2A) activity and the trial’s focus on symptom control (psychosis prevention) align clearly with this category. It is not disease‑modifying for amyloid, tau, inflammation, etc., so 'Neurotransmitter Receptors' is the most specific CADRO match. citeturn1search3turn2search1

Web search results (sources used): 1) StatPearls / NCBI summary describing pimavanserin as a 5‑HT2A antagonist/inverse agonist and pharmacology. citeturn1search2 2) PubMed article demonstrating pimavanserin’s 5‑HT2A inverse agonism in human brain tissue. citeturn1search3 3) Acadia Pharmaceuticals materials (HARMONY study description and press releases) describing the relapse‑prevention design and results in dementia‑related psychosis. citeturn2search0turn2search3 4) FDA / Nuplazid safety and labeling information noting approved indication (Parkinson’s disease psychosis) and safety warnings relevant to dementia‑related psychosis. citeturn0search0turn0search1
